title: ROOT CAUSE - Fix currentProject null in web mode
description:
ROOT CAUSE OF MULTIPLE ISSUES:

File: apps/ui/src/components/views/beads-view.tsx
Lines: 142, 156-165

PROBLEM:
1. Line 142: validateBeads() returns false if !currentProject
2. Line 157: handleCreateClick() calls validateBeads() 
3. If validation fails, Add Issue dialog NEVER opens
4. useBeadsIssues hook also returns early if !currentProject (line 30)
5. Result: NO issues display AND NO dialog can open

ROOT CAUSE:
In web mode (no Electron), there is no file browser to select a project.
currentProject.path is null because no project is selected.

IMPACT:
- Beads Kanban is COMPLETELY BROKEN in web mode
- Cannot view existing issues (34 in DB, 0 in UI)
- Cannot create new issues (dialog won't open)
- DevFlow testing is impossible in web mode

SOLUTION OPTIONS:
1. Add project selector dropdown to UI for web mode
2. Auto-select DevFlow root as default project
3. Allow Beads to work without project context
4. Store selected project in localStorage for web

Files: apps/ui/src/components/views/beads-view.tsx, apps/ui/src/store/app-store.ts

title: Beads issue cards do not show assigned agent information
description:
## Problem

Beads Kanban cards lack visual indicators for agent assignments:

- No agent avatars shown on cards
- No agent names displayed
- No assignment status visible
- Difficult to track who is working on what at a glance

## Current Behavior

Cards show only:
- Title
- Description
- Priority badge (CRITICAL/HIGH/MEDIUM)
- Status (open/in_progress/closed)

## Requested Behavior

Cards should also show:
- Assigned agent avatar (if assigned)
- Agent name on hover or in card footer
- Assignment count badge if multiple agents
- "Unassigned" indicator if no agent

## Proposed Design

```
┌─────────────────────────────────┐
│ PRIORITY: HIGH        [avatar]  │
│ Title: Test Real-time           │
│ Desc: Test real-time...         │
│ status: open    Assigned: John  │
└─────────────────────────────────┘
```

## Benefits

- Better team coordination
- Quick visual scanning
- Prevent duplicate work
- Improved accountability

## Implementation Plan

1. Add agent assignment field to Beads card components
2. Display agent avatar from metadata
3. Add hover tooltip for more details
4. Show "Unassigned" if no agent assigned
5. Add filter by agent option in search
6. Update card styling to accommodate new elements

title: Implement process manager to clean up stale server processes
description:
## Problem

Multiple old server processes run simultaneously, causing confusion:

```bash
$ ps aux | grep 'dev:server'
oxtsotsi  376851  ... npm run dev:server  # jan02 (old)
oxtsotsi  376894  ... sh -c npm run build:packages  # old
oxtsotsi  377399  ... npm run _dev:server  # old
oxtsotsi 1412360  ... npm run dev:server  # 11:19 (old)
oxtsotsi 1412372  ... sh -c npm run build:packages  # old
```

## Issues Caused

- Port conflicts when new servers start
- Confusing process management
- Memory waste (multiple Node.js processes)
- Hard to debug which process is actually serving requests
- Stale processes keep old code running

## Root Cause

1. No PID tracking
2. No cleanup on shutdown
3. Multiple start commands create duplicate processes
4. No process lifecycle management

## Proposed Solution

1. **PID File Tracking**:
   - Store PIDs in `.dev-pids.json`
   - Check for stale PIDs on startup
   - Kill stale processes before starting new ones

2. **Graceful Shutdown Handler**:
   ```javascript
   process.on('SIGINT', () => {
     // Kill all tracked processes
     // Clean up PID file
     process.exit(0);
   });
   ```

3. **Health Check Script**:
   - Verify only one instance of each server running
   - Detect and report port conflicts
   - Auto-kill stale processes

4. **Lock File**:
   - Prevent multiple instances of same server
   - Show helpful error if already running

## Implementation

See `/tmp/testing_status_update.md` for complete `scripts/dev-start.mjs` implementation that includes:
- PID file management
- Stale process cleanup
- Graceful shutdown
- Colored console output

## Success Criteria

- Only one backend server process running
- Only one frontend server process running
- Stale processes automatically cleaned on startup
- Graceful shutdown on Ctrl+C
- Clear error if trying to start already-running server
- No port conflicts

title: Enhance with AI feature shows no loading state and provides no user feedback
description:
## Problem

When clicking the "Enhance with AI" button in the Add Feature dialog:

- No loading indicator/spinner appears
- No enhancement is applied to the prompt text
- No error message is shown to the user
- Silent failure - user does not know if it is working or failed
- Button remains clickable (no disabled state)

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Navigate to Board view (http://localhost:3007/board)
2. Click "Add Feature" button
3. Enter description: "Create a user dashboard"
4. Click "Enhance with AI" button
5. Observe no visual feedback, no text change, no error message

## Expected Behavior

- Show loading spinner/progress indicator
- Button should become disabled during enhancement
- Prompt text should be enhanced with better detail
- Show success message when complete
- Show error message if it fails

## Actual Behavior

Silent failure with no user feedback whatsoever.

## Root Cause

1. Backend server was down (now fixed)
2. Poor UX design - no loading states implemented
3. No error handling for API failures

## Fix Recommendations

1. Add loading state (spinner/progress) during enhancement
2. Disable button while enhancing to prevent double-clicks
3. Show success message when complete with preview of enhanced text
4. Show error message if fails with retry button
5. Add timeout mechanism (e.g., 30 seconds)
6. Consider adding preview/confirm dialog before applying enhancement
7. Add optimistic UI update for better perceived performance

title: HTTP 504 Gateway Timeout on Claude usage endpoint
description:
## Problem

Claude usage statistics endpoint times out with 504 Gateway Timeout error:

```
[HTTP] GET /api/claude/usage failed:
Error: HTTP 504: Gateway Timeout - The Claude CLI took too long to respond
```

## Impact

- Usage statistics not loading in UI
- May indicate Claude CLI performance issues
- Poor user experience (slow loading spinner)
- Could affect other Claude API calls

## Frequency

- 2 errors in 5 minutes during testing
- Recurring pattern observed

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Open DevFlow at http://localhost:3007
2. Wait for page to load
3. Open browser console (F12)
4. Observe 504 timeout errors after ~30 seconds

## Expected Behavior

- Usage statistics should load quickly
- Fallback to cached data if API slow
- Show helpful error message if truly unavailable

## Actual Behavior

- HTTP 504 Gateway Timeout after 30+ seconds
- No user-facing error message
- Usage popover shows "Usage: 0 / 4" (incorrect)
- Console shows repeated timeout errors

## Root Cause Analysis

1. Claude CLI taking too long to respond
2. No caching mechanism for usage data
3. No timeout handling in frontend
4. Possible infinite loop or blocking operation in CLI

## Proposed Solutions

### Immediate (High Priority)

1. **Add Caching Layer**:
   - Cache usage data for 5 minutes
   - Return stale cache on timeout
   - Background refresh after cache expires

2. **Increase Timeout**:
   - Current: ~30 seconds
   - Increase to 60 seconds for usage endpoint
   - Add proper timeout error handling

3. **Loading State**:
   - Show loading spinner in Usage popover
   - Display "Loading usage stats..." message
   - Hide error from console (handle gracefully)

### Long-term (Medium Priority)

4. **Background Polling**:
   - Poll usage endpoint every 2 minutes
   - Update UI silently in background
   - Never block UI for usage data

5. **Optimize Claude CLI**:
   - Investigate why CLI is slow
   - Profile the usage calculation
   - Optimize or cache CLI results

## Files to Update

- `apps/ui/src/components/claude-usage-popover.tsx` - Add loading state
- `apps/server/src/routes/claude/usage.ts` - Add caching
- `apps/server/src/lib/claude-cli-client.ts` - Optimize CLI calls

## Success Criteria

- Usage statistics load in <3 seconds or show cached data
- No 504 errors in console
- User sees loading indicator while fetching
- Graceful fallback to cached data on timeout
- Clear error message if truly unavailable

title: Implement error throttling for 300+ repetitive console errors
description:
## Problem

The browser console is flooded with repetitive error messages:

- 300+ errors logged
- Same error repeated hundreds of times
- Makes debugging difficult
- Degrades browser performance
- Hard to find legitimate errors

## Examples Found

```
[ERROR] [HttpApiClient] WebSocket error: Event
(repeats 208+ times)

[ERROR] [HTTP] POST /api/features/list failed
(repeats 20+ times)

[ERROR] IPC connection failed
(repeats 15+ times)
```

## Impact

- Difficult to debug real issues
- Console becomes unusable
- Performance degradation (memory usage increases)
- Developer experience suffers

## Proposed Solution

1. Implement error throttling (max 5 errors per type)
2. Add error aggregation: "WebSocket error: happened 208 times"
3. Use error tracking service (Sentry)
4. Add debug mode toggle for verbose logging
5. Clear old errors periodically
6. Show error count in UI instead of spamming console

## Implementation Example

```javascript
// Error throttling example
const errorCounts = new Map();
const MAX_LOGGED_ERRORS = 5;

function logError(error) {
  const key = error.message;
  const count = errorCounts.get(key) || 0;

  if (count < MAX_LOGGED_ERRORS) {
    console.error(error);
    errorCounts.set(key, count + 1);
  } else if (count === MAX_LOGGED_ERRORS) {
    console.error(`${error.message} (occurred ${count + 1} times)`);
    errorCounts.set(key, count + 1);
  }

  // Send to error tracking service silently
  sendToErrorTracking(error);
}
```

## Files to Update

- apps/ui/src/lib/http-api-client.ts (main culprit)
- apps/ui/src/components/views/beads-view/hooks/use-beads-issues.ts
- apps/ui/src/components/agent-activity-context.tsx
- apps/ui/src/routes/__root.tsx

## Success Criteria

- Console shows max 5 errors per unique error type
- After threshold, shows aggregated count
- All errors still tracked in background
- Debug mode can be toggled for full logging
- Performance improves (less memory usage)

title: Create unified dev script that starts both backend and frontend servers
description:
## Problem

Users must manually run two separate commands to start DevFlow:

- `npm run dev:server` (port 3008)
- `npm run dev:web` (port 3007)

This is:
- Confusing for new users
- Error-prone (easy to forget one)
- Poor developer experience
- Inconsistent with modern dev tools

## Current Behavior

```bash
# User must run two separate terminals:
terminal 1$ npm run dev:server
terminal 2$ npm run dev:web
```

## Requested Behavior

```bash
# Single command starts everything:
$ npm run dev
# Both servers start automatically
```

## Proposed Solution

1. Install `npm-run-all` package:
   ```bash
   npm install --save-dev npm-run-all
   ```

2. Update package.json scripts:
   ```json
   {
     "scripts": {
       "dev": "npm-run-all --parallel dev:server dev:web",
       "dev:server": "npm run build:packages && npm run _dev:server",
       "dev:web": "npm run build:packages && npm run _dev:web"
     }
   }
   ```

## Alternative: Custom Script

Create `scripts/dev-start.mjs` that:
1. Kills old server processes cleanly
2. Starts both servers in parallel
3. Monitors server health
4. Provides colored console output
5. Handles graceful shutdown on Ctrl+C

See `/tmp/testing_status_update.md` for full implementation.

## Benefits

- Single command to start everything
- Better developer experience
- Consistent with industry standards
- Easier for new contributors
- Process management included

## Success Criteria

- Single `npm run dev` command works
- Both servers start successfully
- Servers restart on file changes
- Graceful shutdown on Ctrl+C
- Clear console output showing both servers
